text: I've beaten the nes version without cheats, warps, or save states, though I did make save states just before several points where I knew I'd have to practice, and being able to reload state made it far less tedious than having to go back to the beginning of the game and get there again to practice more. I did, however, put it all together for one continuous state-free run of the game. Very hard though.

text: Good point. Well, what can I say? I called it a port for nearly five years, and old habbits die hard...
author: TAGMOMG

text: You can call it a "sequel-remake" of sorts. IT mimics a lot of things of the original game but it's still a new installment taking place after that one, a not the "same game being ported". Think about of Gunstar Future Heroes compared with the original Gunstar Heroes. Or think about what Metal Gear Solid 2 does compared with Metal Gear Solid. Different games that should be considered as separate titles, despite their similarities.
author: Albert Wesker

text: Well, I always thought it was the same, but I only found out receantly that it's WAY different. (NES had 13 stages, SNES had only 7, and that's just the begining!) But still, I like to think it's a port. A port with a lot of things different, but a port nontheless.
